seg.seg: (Having heard this, countless beings) obtain the (Arhat-)dignity. All exit. || In the Maitreyasamiti-Nāṭ(aka,

the 25th act, with the name “The Showing of the (Great) Hells” [Nirayanidarśana]) has come to an end. || (Now this dialog) [is] to be understood [as taking place] at the (northern) side (of the Kukkuṭapāda-mountain). Thereupon, the venerable Buddha-god Maitreya reflects

(in the sixth hour of the day on the heart [and] mind [and] deeds) of the beings (to be freed): “The many beings [and] the people, who in their existences (together with me) according my teaching had striven for (the wish) for redemption,

(these were redeemed by me. And furthermore, [the beings], which were [beings] having a (good) mind, these not only by my turning the wheel of the Law [but also] by seeing my magic power, (with which the wall of the Kukkuṭapāda-mountain was broken)
(by ten millions and countless numbers have acquired the benefits [of salvation]. Those beings, however, with a small [and] dry mind, these

(by my bringing forth of exceedingly great) magic power, (having acquired the benefits [of salvation],) were redeemed. And now these beings, by whom really and truly (the wish) to acquire the benefits [of salvation] according to my teaching

(has been striven for), [they] are not [yet] (released from the sufferings of the Saṃsāra). Therefore, I must bring forth openly some really and truly great magic power openly. And thus: || In the tune “Horse”: || All (previous Buddhas),

(the teachers, in order to drive away the Kleśas) have revealed the good feast [and] magic power. Now (by me also) this feast shall be revealed [and] by magic powers (shall) the [beings] of the five existences (be delighted!” 1. ||)

(After him having reflected in that way) in the three-thousand-fold world the earth is moving in a six-fold way: || In the tune Bahudantaka: || It [scil. the earth] goes towards the sunrise, it goes back towards the sunset, [and] it goes towards the North

[it goes] (back towards the South, [it goes] to the centre, [it goes] back to the ends.) The water (wells up) in the ocean; (the divine palaces) tremble, divine voices are raised; divine instruments are sounding. It is raining divine flowers,
... (die Erde(?) [und]) das Wasser im Ozean beben.
... (the earth(?) [and]) the water in the ocean are shaking.

(Kuśeśaya- [and] Mandāraka-flowers are floating in [the] air) filled with sandal-wood [and] jewelry. The earth [lit. earth god] is sprinkled with a fragrant rain, the place and seat of the Buddha-god is adorned, (the entourage, above and below,) gathers
Besprengt wird die Erde mit einem Wohlgeruchsregen, geschmückt wird der Sitz des Buddha, gesammelt wird ...
The earth is sprayed with a rain of fragrance, the seat of the Buddha is decorated, gathered is ...
(1. ||) Thereupon the Māra-god [named] Sumati is delighted. Together with the host of the Parinirmitavaśavartin-gods, [the gods] Sunirmita, Saṃtuṣita, Suyāma, [the god] Indra [gather]

(together with the four divine) kings, according to the plans of the world, (and also the Nāgas, the Asuras, the Yakṣas, the Kumbhāṇḍas), the Kiṃnaras, the Gandharvas, each with their host of their own entourage, (through the power) of the Buddha-god, the teacher,
(and also the rich and young in the 84.000) jewelled cities, (including the) beings (in the city Ketumatī) in [their] ten millions and countless numbers, on the north side of the Kukkuṭapāda-mountain

p.note: The attribution of this fragment to act 26 and the connection to A 287 is expounded in (pace 203-204, who originally places it in act 20/21). The colophon of act 25 thus is to be found in line a2; lines a3 through b7 already are part of act 26. Line b7 runs parallel to MaitrHami 26, 1a26; a3ff. run parallel to MaitrSiŋgim 26, 1a (Taf. 181, r.1-3) (36-41).
The transcription and translation here include the text from fragment A 287 (unlinked passages)!

Two fragments of a manuscript which includes A 251 - A 294 (cf. 64-65). A 287 contains part of the left side of this leaf, while A 259 contains the right half, containing the ends of several lines. The latter fragment is considered to be lost.
Sides have been swapped here as against the original publication in 134 and as already suggested in (Nachträge): 256, 42, 203-4 and 57II, 65II, 81I, 125II and 163II.
Sides have been swapped here (as against the original publication) following the fragment A 259; see 42, 203-204 and 81I, 98I, 125II and 163II.
There is a gap of about 12 syllables at the beginning of this line; 43 prefer to read [n.] instead of [t.] (as in ).
The tune Yuk 'horse' matches a tune Yakwe in TB, which also helps in determining the metre: 4x12 syllables, rhythm 5/7 (45, fn. 71).
pākraśi yalyi: this pāda is one syllable too long; 45, fn. 72, suggest to read pākär 'apparent' instead of pākraśi.
The tune bahudantāka also appears in TB; it has 4x25 syllables, rhythm 5/5/4/4/4/3. This strophe ends in line b5.
The syllable ri of risaṃ is still readable on fragment A 287 (46, fn. 81).
